Somewhere in England, 1914-18, the days of trench warfare.
The first New Zealand expeditionary force in the service dress of the day,
lemon squeezer hats, acres of brass and yards of patties,
are reviewed on Salisbury Plain by his majesty King George V.
Wartime Prime Minister Bill Massey and Sir Joseph Ward were there too.
There wasn't much transport, then.
Of course, there were the mounted rifles,
but foot sluggers were genuine foot sluggers.
Then as now, the Kiwi was recognized as a soldier with initiative,
a man of action who had sailed halfway round the world to defend his homeland down under.

This is different warfare, mobile and fast, the day of the Blitzkrieg and air power.
Changed military techniques called for new training methods and new equipment.

The Kiwis proved themselves readily adaptable. Having mastered the waterless wastes of the deserts, they had no trouble in overcoming the pressing problems of a few days' leave in Cairo. Somewhere in the Pacific, jungle warfare.

The military township of Waiuru today is one of the country's most vital communities, well equipped to house the new army and its families.
